entry.title: SAP AIDevCon 2025: A Day That Redefined AI Innovation
entry.content:
What an absolute triumph yesterday was! The SAP AIDevCon 2025 event on November 8th wasn't just another conference; it was a powerful convergence of ideas, talent, and technology that truly demonstrated the revolutionary potential of Business AI.

The air in the venue was charged with incredible energy and vibrancy. We saw over 50+ passionate participants from more than 26+ diverse corporates and 3 key Indian universities come together. The goal was simple but profound: to not just talk about AI, but to build it.

Igniting Innovation: The Hands-on Experience

The day kicked off with invaluable networking‚Äîthe kind that sparks future projects‚Äîfollowed by an inspiring keynote address from our VP, Head of APAC. This set the stage for the true excitement: the hands-on experience.

Our participants didn't just attend sessions; they became builders. They immersed themselves in cutting-edge SAP BTP AI services, specifically using:

  • SAP Build for powerful low-code process automation.

  • Document AI to intelligently process unstructured business documents.

  • Translation Hub to instantly break down language barriers in applications.

The highlight was the intensive hackathon. Our audience, a perfect blend of industry experts and bright university students, worked in fierce yet collaborative teams. The atmosphere was one of positive vibes and shared goals, where they had to train, exhibit, and deliver industry-ready prototypes.

SAP Build Sessions

Hands-On Sessions

Breakthrough Prototypes: Solving Real Problems

The solutions developed were not academic exercises‚Äîthey were direct answers to critical business challenges. The teams built phenomenal prototypes that showcased the speed and scale possible with SAP BTP AI, focusing on real-world impact:

  1. Dispute Management: Creating smart solutions to automate and accelerate complex financial and operational dispute resolution.

  2. Piracy Protection: Leveraging AI to build robust, automated systems for safeguarding digital assets and intellectual property.

  3. Wellbeing: Developing AI-driven applications to enhance employee and user well-being through proactive insights and personalised support.

This entire day was a masterclass in learning, teamwork, and execution, all driven by the powerful capabilities of SAP Business Technology Platform.

Super Energetic - SAP Community

Gratitude for Our Ecosystem of Heroes

A monumental event like this is only possible because of a dedicated community. A huge and sincere thank you goes out to:

  • Our incredible mentors and volunteers whose guidance transformed ideas into working code.

  • All the brilliant participants for bringing their enthusiasm and skill.

  • The SAP Leadership for championing the vision of an AI-first future.

  • The unsung heroes in IT, Security, and Admin, and each and every hero behind the scenes, whose seamless work made the entire event feel effortless.

Networking

Hackathon - Planning

SAP Document AI Sessions

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation by College Students

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon - Presentation

Hackathon Winner

That's me!

What's Next? A Teaser!

The energy and innovation we witnessed at SAP AIDevCon 2025 proved one thing: the appetite for building intelligent, transformative solutions is immense.

This event was a resounding success, and we're already hard at work planning something even bigger and better. Stay tuned, because we are preparing to launch the next, even more exciting, version of AIDevCon very soon!

Keep learning, keep building, and we look forward to welcoming you back to the innovation floor.

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2511
entry.content:
SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2511

With the introduction of the new release 2511, this blog post presents an overview of the latest features and enhancements. The release has been available since November 15th and serves as the successor to the release 2508. Some highlights of the 2511 release include the Analytical table with RAP and SAP Fiori Elements, the ADT editor for Business Configuration Sets and the Graphical Modeler for CDS. 

The list of all new features can be found on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment page

You can find live demos of the following features in the recording of the Customer & Partner Roundtable #29: Graphical Modeler for CDS, Analytical table with RAP and SAP Fiori Elements, ghost text for keyword completion in ADT.

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  • Using ghost text as new default for keyword completion, when you start typing a keyword, ADT now shows the best matching suggestion as ghost text at the current position within your source code by default (details)
  • Editor for E-Mail templates, it allows the creation of pre-delivered e-mail templates for rendering e-mails (details)
  • Editor for Business Configuration Sets (details)
  • ADT Objects for SAP Application Interface Framework (details)
  • Enhancements in the Dependency Analyzer for CDS Table Functions (details)
  • Support of Graphical Call Timeline on macOS for ABAP Traces (details)
  • Logon with Versions of ADT Older than 3.46 no Longer Possible

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

  • Log RAP-based change documents, this feature enables the logging of RAP-based customer-defined change documents as business events in business event logging (details)
  • RAP change operations for data records, with the introduction of the new syntax addition read entity MyEntity with changes (all fields | fields ( ... ) ) with ... result data(rdc), an application developer may now access the corresponding change operations of a data record processed within the transaction
  • RAP global side effects, they are an optional part of a RAP behavior definition that define interdependencies among BO properties that trigger a reload of the affected properties on the user interface. Global side effects are those side effects that are defined without any source properties or source entities and can be invoked by an end user with a dedicated key stroke

SAP Fiori

  • Fiori Analytical Table - Read-Only, you miss the ABAP List Viewer (ALV) in Fiori with simple analytical capabilities? The Fiori Analytical Table will be introduced to combine the transactional and light-weight analytical world. RAP needs to support further OData URL to ABAP SQL mapping with analytical capabilities. For advanced analytics with multi-dimensional analytical reporting please check the analytical clients (details)

Business Configuration

  • Support of Business Configuration Sets with a new ADT editor (see above) and new released API to extract the business configuration data in target tenants (details)
  • Hide draft related features, all features related to draft handling can be hidden from the UI while the draft functionality remains active in the background (details)

Integration

  • Predefined custom fields, you can now add predefined custom fields to OData consumption models (details)
  • New CDS views in business event logging, the following CDS views have been released: Business Event Header Data, Business Event Payload, Business Event Data, Business Event Activity (see Business Event Header Data, Business Event Payload, Business Event Data, Business Activity)
  • RFC communication via communication targets, a new enhancement in RFC communication introduces the use of communication targets and application destinations for outbound RFC communication. This ensures more secure and efficient communication processes

Event Consumption Model

  • Button Publish Locally for EEEC authorizations, the Publish Locally button in the event consumption model allows users to generate authorizations for the EEEC within the SAP_BR_DEVELOPER role (details)

Reuse Services

  • You can now reset content to the standard units of measurement delivered by SAP using the released API CL_UOM_CONTENT_HANDLER (details)
  • You can now convert SAP codes to external codes and vice versa using class CL_CONVERSION_EXT_INT (details)

XCO Library

  • You can now create, read, update, and delete business configuration sets with the XCO API (details)
  • You can now generate static external entities
  • You can now also customize the borders of individual cells using the Excel API

Maintain Translations

  • You can now use the Maintain Translations app for custom translations of application job entities. Additionally, we've removed the limit on the total amount of texts you can add and translate in a translation project. You can now add an unlimited number of texts (details)

ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC)

  • Partner support in ATC check "Usage of APIs", when using an SAP BTP ABAP environment as the central check system, the ATC check Usage of APIs allows you to specify classic APIs of SAP partners. This enables customers to improve their custom code with regards to Clean Core compliance when using APIs of certified SAP partners
  • Approve ATC Exemptions App: Receive E-Mail notifications, you can now subscribe to receive e-mail notifications when an ATC exemption request was approved (details)

Lifecycle Management

  • Manage Software Components, Software Components configured with the role Target are now protected from changes and cannot be recorded on transports. This feature is designed to prevent inadvertent modifications to components, ensuring their integrity and stability (details)
  • Manage Software Components, you can now use the safe remote deletion feature. It is designed to ensure system integrity by preventing the accidental deletion of active repositories or branches and prevents the creation of ghost software components (details)

Technical Monitoring

  • Capturing of PlanViz (PLV) files now possible in the Capture Request Statistics app, and subsequent download in the SQL Statement Analysis app (details)

entry.title: Common configuration issues: Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Let's look at the common issues that we may have while setting up Joule with SuccessFactors:

  1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing
  2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed
  3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA
  4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud
  5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working
  6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

==================================================================================

So let us take a look at the issue and how to fix them:

1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing

While running the booster, we got the error message:

‚ÄúSome of the entitlements are not available in the selected subaccount <XXXX>. Please either add them or select a subaccount with different provider or region.‚Äù

Fix: 

Go to BTP Global Account -> Entity Assignments.

Check if Joule and SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition service are entitled to the subaccount.

If Joule is not available in BTP Global Account -> Procure Joule

 

2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed

While running the Joule booster, we got the error message:

 

Fix: Please follow the KBA to setup accordingly: 

3539985 - Synchronization failed between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services when using booster for Joule setup

 

3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA

While running the booster, we got the error message:

Cause: S/4HANA system is not registered with BTP global account.

Fix: Double check the steps ‚ÄúRegister SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in BTP Global Account‚Äù in the mission.

 

4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud

There are several reasons might cause this issue, please follow below to check:

4.1 Double check the step ‚ÄúUpdate Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud‚Äù in mission

Follow the last step to paste the URL of your Joule application into the Trusted Content text box and click Save.

4. 2  Try opening the system in an Incognito window to rule out browser cache issues.
If Joule appears there, clear your browser cache and cookies before accessing it again in normal mode.

4.3 When logging int S/4HANA Public Cloud, check the domain of Cloud Identity Services that is used during login (e.g. ending with ondemand.com or cloud.sap) => in BTP Cockpit -> Joule Subaccount -> Trust Configuration -> Select the Cloud Identity Services used for application logon -> check if the ‚ÄúDomain‚Äù is set to the same domain used in S4.

4.4 Check in Cloud Identity Services if the hosting application (S/4Public Cloud) and Joule application are configured in exact same way (IDP/Conditional authentication)

 

5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working

5.1 Cause: CDM content not synchronised

Fix: In the Channel Manager of Build Workzone, please click on "Report" to check how many apps / roles were actually synchronised.

5. 2 Cause: User lacking role assignments.

Fix:  Check whether the logged in user actually have the required groups assigned.

Check the sample prompts and corresponding roles here.

5. 3 Double check below steps in the mission

  • Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone
  • Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

Cause: In rare cases the automated integration between Joule and S/4HANA might fail.

Fix: Check if the CN name used in Destination S4HANA_PUB_SSO fits to the CN name maintained in S/4HANA.
In case of mismatch open an incident with CA-JOULE

CN name in above screenshot need to match between BTP Destination and S/4 Communication System (Signing Certificate Issuer in below screenshot).

 

If the issue still persists or any other issues not listed here, open a ticket under component CA-JOULE.

 

Cheers, 

Happy Learning

SAP Business AI RIG team

entry.title: SAP Ariba SLP - MDG attachment Integration - Making the Impossible Possible
entry.content:
The integration between SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (SLP) and SAP Master Data Governance for Suppliers (MDG-S) enables extensive synchronization of supplier master data across both systems through choreographed business scenarios. The SLP-MDG integration supports bidirectional data exchange between SAP Ariba SLP and MDG-S, ensuring consistent supplier master data across both applications. If you would like to know the supported scenarios within this integration, refer to the standard documentation here

In this section, we will cover the details of integrating attachments from Ariba SLP into SAP MDG or SAP ERP systems.  Let's first discuss the potential documents a supplier will upload to Ariba SLP when they register or update their existing registration. 

  • Quality and other Certificates
  • Tax and Financial Documents
  • Supporting Documents that the buyer wants the supplier to upload
  • Contractual or Risk documents

Attachments in Ariba SLP are not restricted to the above documents it could be any Ariba acceptable format that pass the inbuilt Virus test while uploading on the SAP Business Network for Suppliers (which is the UI for the Supplier when trying to register to a Buyer's SLP) 

Secondly, attachment-related inputs can be collected in the Registration, Modular, and Qualification Questionnaire. The SAP Ariba SLP product team recommends receiving certifications with Validity dates through Modular questionnaires only. 

Lastly, Questionnaire respondents can add attachments to a supplier management questionnaire as a response to any of the following questions:

  • Answer type of Attachment.

  • Answer type of Certificate, where one of the certificate detail fields is an attachment field.

  • Any other answer type, with Participant can add additional comments and attachments set to Yes

In the first two cases, the attachment is a direct answer to the question. In the third case, the attachment is an optional addition to the response and can be added with or without a comment. For more details about the attachment sizes supported refer to the help documentation here.

Our Solution: A Dedicated Integration Package for Attachments

Given the context above, customers seeking attachment integration typically fall into two categories:

  1. Existing Users: Customers already live with the standard SAP Ariba SLP integration (via SAP Integration Suite, Managed Gateway for Spend and Business Network/CIG).

  2. New Implementations: Customers planning or currently implementing the standard SAP SLP-MDG/ERP integration through CIG.

Why This Package is Essential

Our integration package is designed to work for both customer groups because it does not disrupt the standard SAP Ariba CIG integration for Supplier Data Integration.

Instead, we leverage SAP Ariba's open APIs and standard SAP MDG APIs, making the package highly consumable, robust, and extensible for future scenarios. We strongly recommend that customers first implement the standard CIG-based integration for core vendor master data integration and then utilize this package to seamlessly supplement it with attachment integration.

Let's now take a look at the architecture at a high level to see how to achieve this.

High-Level Architecture

The integration package, which we have developed and deployed for customers, operates on a continuous polling mechanism:

  1. It checks SAP Ariba SLP at regular intervals for the latest created and changed suppliers.

  2. It identifies suppliers that are Approved and have a Registered status.

  3. Using SAP Ariba Open APIs, it securely transfers the attachments from the questionnaires to the target system (SAP MDG or SAP ERP), which is configurable based on customer requirements.

  4. The package includes the necessary ABAP code to accurately add the attachment to the SAP MDG Change Request or the SAP ERP Business Partner record.

Benefits of deploying this integration package for the Ariba SLP ‚Üí SAP MDG / SAP ERP BP Attachment Integration would be,

  • Fully automated attachment flow, zero manual intervention
  • Reduced onboarding cycle time, Accelerates Supplier Onboarding
  • Lower administrative overhead for Supplier Management teams in Customers
  • More consistent and complete supplier records, strengthening compliance and Auditability
  • Enhances Data Quality and Governance
  • Supports Multiple Integration Scenarios (Both SAP MDG and SAP ERP systems)

Customers have reported a 40-60% reduction in manual effort during supplier onboarding, based on the volume of attachments they handle. 

If you have any further questions, please leave a comment below or send your inquiries to the email CoE_AI_PlanningSpendExec@global.corp.sap. We will be happy to get back to you.

entry.title: AI-Assisted User Learning & Change Management ‚Äì HPFA Idea Project
entry.content:
Anyone who has been part of an SAP project knows this feeling: the system is ready, the processes are solid‚Ä¶ but getting everyone trained and confident takes far more time than expected. Teams can spend weeks analysing process changes, figuring out who needs what training, and then writing pages and pages of content from scratch. It‚Äôs slow, expensive, and honestly, quite exhausting for everyone involved.

This is exactly the pain point our team wanted to tackle.

Over the past months, we have been working on AI-assisted user learning and change management ‚Äî a simple idea with a big impact. Instead of manually rebuilding training from zero for every project, the app reads SAP Signavio, Cloud ALM and other process data and turns it into clear, role-based training content automatically. In early pilots, tasks that used to take 10 days could be done in a single day. And the content stays consistent and aligned with SAP Best Practices.

The goal is pretty straightforward:
to help people learn faster, reduce project stress, and make adoption feel smooth instead of overwhelming.

This project is now part of the Hasso Plattner Founders‚Äô Award ‚Äì Scaling Innovation challenge, and we‚Äôre honestly excited (and a little proud) to share it with the SAP community. The award focuses on ideas that bring real, long-term value to customers and to SAP ‚Äî and we believe this one really does.

If you feel the same, it would mean a lot to us if you could support the idea with a quick boost.
Every click helps the project get more visibility, and it motivates the team to keep pushing the innovation further.

*** [Click here to boost the Idea Project] *** 
(Your support genuinely makes a difference.)

And a big thank you to everyone who already tested, challenged, or encouraged us along the way. This project grew because of real collaboration, curiosity, and a shared wish to make SAP learning easier for people everywhere.

Let‚Äôs make change a bit lighter ; and a lot more human.

If you‚Äôre an SAP partner, you‚Äôve probably heard ‚ÄúAI agents‚Äù mentioned in every second customer conversation lately.  The thing is‚Ä¶ most teams still aren‚Äôt sure how to use them in real projects.

We‚Äôll start by demystifying SAP‚Äôs agentic landscape‚Äîwhat agents are, how they think and act, and when they‚Äôre the right tool.  Then we‚Äôll roll up our sleeves and show how you can use Joule Studio‚Äôs low-code / no-code agent builder to design content-based agents that plug into SAP BTP, SAP Build, and your existing processes.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won‚Äôt find them.

And that‚Äôs exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can‚Äôt and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP ‚Äî it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I‚Äôll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Onboarding to SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition for SAP BTP Subaccount
entry.content:
Step 1: Prerequisites

  1. Open your Identity Authentication admin environment.

    1. Open your SAP BTP Subaccount 
    2. Click on Trust Configuration under security tab
    3. Select Custom Identity Provider for Applications
    4. In the Identity Provider click on Administrator Console
  2. Choose the User Groups tile.

  3. Click + Add and create the following groups:

Note: The Name and Display Name must be identical. They must match exactly as listed below to align with the Identity Provisioning transformation code. If you modify any name, update the transformation logic accordingly.

  • Workzone_Admin

  • Workzone_Area_Admin

  • Workzone_Support_Admin

  • Workzone_Page_Content_Admin

  • Workzone_End_User

  • Workzone_User_Type_public

       4. Navigate to User Management.

       5. Assign yourself to the Workzone_Admin group.

Step 2: Run the Booster

  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, open your Global Account.

  2. From the left-side menu, select Boosters.

  3. Locate Get Started with SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition and click Start.

Step 3: Post-Booster Configuration

Connect Your Subaccount to Identity Provisioning

Prerequisites:

  • The integration with the Identity Provisioning service supports only one active Identity Authentication tenant. Before you start the configuration, open the cockpit, Security  Trust Configuration, and verify that you have only one active Identity Authentication trust configuration in the list. The default IdP, sap.default, is not relevant to the flow and can be ignored for this requirement. After the connection is formed, you can configure additional active IdPs.

  • If you already have an active Identity Authentication tenant, you are required to reconnect it to the Identity Provisioning service after you've modified it.

Connector Setup for User & Group Provisioning:

Note: This step is required only if you don't already have an active tenant with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition connector configured for your subaccount.

  1. Open the Site Manager:

    • In BTP cockpit, navigate to Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions.

    • Open the subscription for SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

  2. From the left menu, go to Settings ‚Üí Identity Provisioning.

  3. Click Connect.

Step 4: Run the Configurator

  1. Access the Site Manager as follows: In the SAP BTP cockpit, Services  Instances and Subscriptions, click on the subscription to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition in the Subscriptions table to access the application.
  2. Open the Configurator screen from the left-side menu.

4.1 Create a Destination to SAP SuccessFactors (Optional)

The step Create a Destination to SAP SuccessFactors is optional and can be skipped if not required.

4.2 Set Up Environment

In this step, select the domain type - Default and then click Trigger Setup to complete the  configuration steps required for the setup of your tenant.

4.3 Configure Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning

In this step, you'll need to manually configure Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning to enable user authentication and user provisioning.

4.3.1 : Create an app in Identity Authentication

 

  1. Download the metadata(This will be used in step 4)
  2. Open the administration console for SAP Cloud Identity Services. To do so, in SAP BTP cockpit, go to Security -> Trust Configuration, click the link pointing to your active Identity Authentication and add /admin to the URL.
  3. Go to Applications & Resources -> Applications and click +Add to add a new application from type SAP BTP Solution. Provide a meaningful name such as SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Select the protocol type SAML 2.0.
  4. Open the SAML 2.0 Configuration editor of the application you've created, and upload the service provider metadata file that you‚Äôve downloaded from the configurator. Save your changes.
  5. Open the Subject Name Identifier editor of the application, and change the basic configuration attribute from User ID to Global User ID.

4.3.2 Set Identity Authentication as a source system

  1. In the administration console for SAP Cloud Identity Services, go to the Administrators tile and create a technical user (of type System)
  2. Client ID will be automatically generated
  3. Under the Secrets click on Add button give a meaningful description and click Save. 

Note: A secret will be generated, copy this and save it as won't be visible again

 


  • Make sure Manage Users and Manage Groups authorization roles are enabled for the technical user. This way, you can create, edit and delete users and groups in the Identity Authentication user store.
  • Go to Admin Console -> Identity  Provisioning -> select source system -> Click on Add -> Give a name to a source system and select type Identity Authentication and save it.
  • Go to Properties -> and add properties as mentioned below:

Mandatory Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

Type

Enter: HTTP

URL

<Identity Provider URL from prerequisites Step 1>

ProxyType

Enter: Internet

The Identity Authentication service is a cloud solution and is outside of your company on-premise infrastructure.

Authentication

Enter your authentication method:

  • BasicAuthentication

User

<Client ID from Step 4.3.2 - (2)>

Password

<Secret from Step 4.3.2 - (3)>

Optional Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

  • ias.<property_name>
  • scim.<property_name>

When using SCIM API version 2, property names start with ias prefix, for example: ias.user.unique.attribute.

When using SCIM API version 1, property names start with scim prefix, for example: scim.user.unique.attribute.

For more information, see List of Properties. Use the main search or filter properties by Name or System Type columns.

ias.user.filter

When specified, only those users matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: name.familyName eq "Smith" and addresses.country eq "US"

This filter will read only users whose name is "Smith" and are living in the United States.

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: User Search

ias.group.filter

When specified, only those groups matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: displayName eq "ProjectTeam1"

This filter will read only groups, whose display name is "ProjectTeam1".

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: Group Search

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts

Predefined value: 2

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts.interval

Predefined value: 60

4.3.3 Set SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition as a target system using the following parameters

These parameters are already provided in the configurator tab in the site manager copy all these values mentioned in this step and add it in the target system.

Go to Admin Console -> Identity  Provisioning -> select target system -> Click on Add ->

  • In Details tab give a name to a target system and Type should be SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.
  • Go to Properties tab and maintain below mentioned properties and Save it.

 

Mandatory Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

Type

Enter: HTTP

URL

From the above screenshot Integration url should be added here

ProxyType

Enter: Internet

Authentication

  • BasicAuthentication

User

Provide the value OAuth Client Key mentioned in the above screenshot

Password

Provide the value OAuth Client Secret mentioned in the above screenshot

 

 

Optional Properties

Property Name

Description & Value

  • ias.<property_name>
  • scim.<property_name>

When using SCIM API version 2, property names start with ias prefix, for example: ias.user.unique.attribute.

When using SCIM API version 1, property names start with scim prefix, for example: scim.user.unique.attribute.

For more information, see List of Properties. Use the main search or filter properties by Name or System Type columns.

ias.user.filter

When specified, only those users matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: name.familyName eq "Smith" and addresses.country eq "US"

This filter will read only users whose name is "Smith" and are living in the United States.

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: User Search

ias.group.filter

When specified, only those groups matching the filter expression will be read.

For example: displayName eq "ProjectTeam1"

This filter will read only groups, whose display name is "ProjectTeam1".

For more information, see Identity Directory SCIM API: Group Search

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts

Predefined value: 2

ips.failed.request.retry.attempts.interval

Predefined value: 60

 

4.4 Configure and Run Provisioning Job

  1. Once both Source System and Target System is configured follow below steps to Run Provisioning Job.
  2. Go to Source System already created in the step 4.3.2.
  3. Go to the Jobs tab and Run Read Job.

       4. Go to Identity Provisioning -> Provisioning Logs to verify the job logs, which should display a successful status.

As you complete each of these steps keep ticking the checkboxes and then last step would be to launch the Build Workzone.

 

Reference Documents:
https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-advanced-edition/sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition/prerequisites?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/sap-build-work-zone-advanced-edition?locale=en-US

entry.title: Fueling unrivaled AI and thriving with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
AI is everywhere. But AI with context? That‚Äôs where SAP Partners win.

Join our webinar, ‚ÄúFueling unrivaled AI and thriving with SAP Business Data Cloud,‚Äù
to see how SAP Business Data Cloud becomes the engine of enterprise AI.

In one fast-paced session, we‚Äôll cover:

  • Market expectations and what your customers really want from AI.
  • SAP Business Data Cloud strategy for enterprise data and key personas.
  • How knowledge graphs, AI engineering, agents, and embedded AI unlock smarter outcomes.

You‚Äôll walk away ready to position an end-to-end AI story: from customer expectations and SAP‚Äôs Business AI strategy to how we use data + agentic AI to close the ‚Äúcontext gap.‚Äù

If you‚Äôre ready to elevate your next customer conversation, this hour is worth it.

Register now https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/education/psd/2025/jul/e_oe_te_w_PSD_WEB_00010657.html

Âú®ERPÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÔºåSAPÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÊõ¥Êô∫ËÉΩÁöÑÂºÄÂèëÊñπÂºèÔºö

  • ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑Êâ©Â±ïÔºö‰Ωé‰ª£Á†ÅÊñπÂºèËß£ÂÜ≥Â§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÁöÑÂ∞èÈúÄÊ±Ç
  • ÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊâ©Â±ïÔºöÂü∫‰∫éABAPÁöÑÊ∑±Â∫¶ÂÆöÂà∂ÔºåËß£ÂÜ≥Â§çÊùÇÈúÄÊ±Ç

ÈáçÁÇπÊòØÔºöÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊâ©Â±ïÊñπÂºè‰æùÁÑ∂ÊòØÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑABAPÂºÄÂèëÔºÅ

 

ÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊãìÂ±ïÊñπÂºèÂíå‰º†ÁªüABAP‰ª£Á†ÅÂºÄÂèëÁöÑÂå∫Âà´

Ê†∏ÂøÉ‰∫ãÂÆûÔºö‰∏§ÁßçÊñπÂºèÈÉΩÊòØÂÜôABAP‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂå∫Âà´Âè™ÊòØÂºÄÂèëËßÑËåÉÊõ¥‰∏•Ê†º‰∫Ü

ÂºÄÂèëÊ¥ªÂä®‰º†ÁªüABAPÊñπÂºèÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊãìÂ±ïÊñπÂºèÂ∑ÆÂºÇËØ¥Êòé
ÂºÄÂèëÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÈááÁî®ADTÊàñÂÜÖÁΩÆT-CodeÂøÖÈ°ª‰ΩøÁî®Âü∫‰∫éEclipseÁöÑABAP Development ToolsÔºàADTÔºâ 
Êï∞ÊçÆÊ®°ÂûãÂÆö‰πâÂàõÂª∫Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìË°®(SE11)ÂàõÂª∫CDSÊï∞ÊçÆÂÆö‰πâÂíåÊé•Âè£ËßÜÂõæ‰ΩøÁî®Â£∞ÊòéÂºèCDSËØ≠Ê≥ïÔºåÂÜÖÁΩÆÂÖÉÊï∞ÊçÆÊ≥®Ëß£
‰∏öÂä°ÈÄªËæëÂÆûÁé∞ÁºñÂÜôFunction ModuleÊàñClassÂºÄÂèëRAPË°å‰∏∫ÂÆö‰πâÂíåË°å‰∏∫ÂÆûÁé∞Á±ª‰ΩøÁî®Â£∞ÊòéÂºèCDSËØ≠Ê≥ïÔºåÂÜÖÁΩÆÂÖÉÊï∞ÊçÆÊ≥®Ëß£
ÊúçÂä°Êö¥Èú≤ÊâãÂä®ÂàõÂª∫RFC/BAPIÈÄöËøáService DefinitionËá™Âä®ÁîüÊàêODataÊúçÂä°Ëá™Âä®ÂåñÊúçÂä°ÁîüÊàêÔºåÊ†áÂáÜODataÂçèËÆÆ
UIÂºÄÂèëÂºÄÂèëDynpro/WebDynproÁïåÈù¢

‰ΩøÁî®Business Application StudioÂºÄÂèëFiori‰ª£Á†ÅÁÑ∂ÂêéÈÉ®ÁΩ≤Âà∞S/4HANA‰∏≠

Âü∫‰∫éÂÖÉÊï∞ÊçÆÈ©±Âä®ÁöÑUIÁîüÊàê

ÊùÉÈôêÊéßÂà∂

ÊâãÂä®ÂÆûÁé∞ÊùÉÈôêÊ£ÄÊü•

ÈÄöËøáCDSËÆøÈóÆÊéßÂà∂ÂíåRAPÊéàÊùÉ

Â£∞ÊòéÂºèÊùÉÈôêÊ®°ÂûãÔºåÈõÜÊàêÂà∞Ê°ÜÊû∂‰∏≠

‰ΩÜ‰ªéÊãìÂ±ïÂèØË°åÊÄßËßíÂ∫¶Êù•ÁúãÁöÑÊ†πÊú¨Âå∫Âà´ÊòØÔºåÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊãìÂ±ïÊñπÂºèÈááÁî®‰∫Ü"ÁôΩÂêçÂçï"Êú∫Âà∂Ôºö

  • Âè™ËÉΩ‰ΩøÁî®SAPÂÆòÊñπÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÁ®≥ÂÆöAPIÂíåCDSËßÜÂõæ
  • ËøôÁ°Æ‰øù‰∫Ü‰Ω†ÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÂú®SAPÁ≥ªÁªüÂçáÁ∫ßÊó∂‰∏ç‰ºöÂá∫ÈóÆÈ¢ò

ÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÆûÈôÖÂºÄÂèëÂâçÈúÄË¶ÅÁ°ÆËÆ§Ôºö

  1. ‰∏öÂä°Êâ©Â±ïÁÇπÔºöÁ°ÆËÆ§Ê†áÂáÜÊµÅÁ®ãÊèê‰æõÁöÑBAdIÂíåÊâ©Â±ïÊé•Âè£
  2. Êï∞ÊçÆËÆøÈóÆÔºöÁ°ÆËÆ§ÊâÄÈúÄ‰∏öÂä°Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑCDSËßÜÂõæ
  3. APIÂèØÁî®ÊÄßÔºöÁ°ÆËÆ§ÊâÄÈúÄÂäüËÉΩAPIÁöÑÂèëÂ∏ÉÁä∂ÊÄÅ

ÊúÄÂêéËÆæËÆ°ÁõÆÊ†á‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÔºå‰∏ÄÊó¶Á°ÆËÆ§ÂÆåÊØïÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØÊ†áÂáÜÁöÑABAPÂºÄÂèëÊµÅÁ®ãÔºÅ

 

ÂÆû‰æã

Êé•‰∏ãÊù•‰ª•‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑERPÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÂºÄÂèëÈ°πÁõÆ‰∏∫‰æãÔºå

Ëøô‰∏™Ê°à‰æãÂ∞ÜÂ±ïÁ§∫ÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑ'Ë°®-ÈÄªËæë-ÁïåÈù¢-ÈÉ®ÁΩ≤'ÂÖ®Ê†àÂºÄÂèëÊµÅÁ®ãÔºåÊâÄÊúâ‰ª£Á†ÅÈÉΩËøêË°åÂú®S/4HANAÁ≥ªÁªüÂÜÖÈÉ®

 

Develop an SAP Fiori App to Trigger Purchase Requisitions API

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â∫îÁî®ÂºÄÂèë

entry.title: Authorization management with OpenSearch's Document Level Security - SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
The shift to SAP Cloud Logging service introduces several improvements over its predecessor, the SAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). One major benefit is the ability to use a single Cloud Logging instance across multiple CF spaces and even multiple CF orgs/subaccounts. (For more details, see the blog post Instance Sharing ‚Äì SAP Cloud Logging.)

However, the authorization model is different fromSAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). Application Logging supported only read-only access and implicitly reused CF space permissions.  

Cloud Logging, on the other hand:

  • Supports read/write use cases
  • Allows creating custom content
  • Enables centralization and sharing

In order to support such extended scenarios, Cloud Logging integrates with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) for flexible authentication and authorization.

This document guides on how to leverage Document Level Security (DLS) in OpenSearch Roles (+) IAS Groups to setup flexible authorization. It explains using few common use cases including the prominent one - replicating the familiar space-level separation, based on user's CF Space assignment, within a unified logging instance.

  • OpenSearch Security Model Overview
  • Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security
  • The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID
  • Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)
  • Step 1:Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)
  • Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles
  • Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles
  • Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)
  • Use Case 3: Using Other Fields
  • Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization
  • High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch
  • Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)
  • 1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :
  • 2. DLS and Write Permissions:
  • 3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles
  • 4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

OpenSearch Security Model Overview

OpenSearch's security model provides the foundation for integrating with external Identity Providers (IdPs) like SAP IAS:

ComponentDefinitionIntegration
UsersIndividual accounts accessing OpenSearch.Authenticated via SAP IAS.
OpenSearch Roles

Collections of permissions (read, write, manage) and security filters (DLS).

Cloud Logging ships with default roles, and customers may create additional ones.

The mechanism for authorization.
Backend RolesGroups or roles assigned to the user within the SAML/OIDC Identity Provider ‚Äî in this case SAP IAS Group names.The bridge between SAP IAS and OpenSearch Roles.
Roles MappingThe link that connects IAS groups (backend roles) to OpenSearch roles. How users inherit OpenSearch permissions.

Note: 

Since IAS groups are customer-defined, Cloud Logging can only pre-map the IAS group that should serve as instance admin to OpenSearch‚Äôs all_access role. All other mappings must be configured by the customer.

Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security

  • Index-Level Security controls which indices a user can access.

  • Document-Level Security (DLS) controls which documents inside an index a user can access.

To restrict users to logs from a specific CF space, you apply DLS.

The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID

To achieve security separation, every log document must contain a field that identifies its CF source. We assume this field is named space_name (mapped as space_name.keyword in OpenSearch).

DLS works by appending a mandatory filter‚Äîan OpenSearch Query DSL statement‚Äîto every search request made by a user assigned to the role. This filter ensures the user only retrieves documents where the space_name.keyword matches their authorized space(s).

Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)

When you have a small number of distinct spaces (e.g., space-A and space-B), and each requires a dedicated authorization group, you create a static OpenSearch Role for each.

Step 1: Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)

  • space-A-read-only
  • space-B-read-only

Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles

We will define two roles, each allowing read-only access to log indices but restricted by DLS.

A. Role for Space-A (role-space-A-read-only)

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Clone the default readall role and name it role-space-A-read-only.
  3. Cluster permissions: cluster_composite_ops_ro
  4. Index Permissions:

    • Index Pattern: logs-*(Specify a pattern like this instead of only specifying an asterisk * to avoid applying DLS to system indices).

    • Index Permissions: Select read
    • Document Level Security: Enter the DLS query for the specific space: 
{
  "term": {
    "space_name.keyword": "space-A"
  }
}‚Äã

B. Role for Space-B (role-space-B-read-only)

Repeat the above steps for role-space-B-read-only, changing the value in the DLS query to "space-B".

Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles

This step links the SAP IAS groups to the newly created security filters.

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Select role-space-A-read-only.

  3. Click the Mapped Users tab and then Manage Mapping.

  4. Under Backend roles, add the SAP IAS group name: space-A-read-only.

Repeat this process for role-space-B-read-only, mapping it to the space-B-read-only backend role.

Crucial Note on Dashboards Access: You must also map these new Backend Roles (space-A-read-only, space-B-read-only)to the OpenSearch role global_tenant_read_access to allow users to see and use shared dashboards and visualizations.

Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)

If you need to define a single role for a department (e.g., Finance) that needs access to a specific list of CF spaces (space-A, space-C, space-D), you can use terms query to add multiple values.

UI Steps for a finance_spaces_read_only Role:

  1. Clone the default OpenSearch Role readall and name it finance_spaces_read_only.

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as explained in Use Case 1.
  3. Document Level Security: Enter the terms query to include all required spaces: 
{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [
      "space-A",
      "space-C",
      "space-D"
    ]
  }
}

Map this role to the relevant SAP IAS group (e.g., finance_spaces_read_only) as explained in Use Case 1.

Use Case 3: Using Other Fields

The same DLS concepts apply to:

  • organization_id

  • organization_name
  • app_name

You can restrict access on any well-defined keyword field stored in your logs. 

Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization

For maximum scalability, instead of creating one OpenSearch role per space, you can create a single role that dynamically substitutes the user‚Äôs backend roles into the DLS query.

This works when IAS group names match the field values ‚Äî for example:

  • finance_space_prod
  • finance_space_staging
  • finance_space_dev

In OpenSearch, the variable ${user.roles} references the list of backend roles (IAS groups) assigned to the user.

UI Steps for a Dynamic Role:

  1. Create a single OpenSearch Role (e.g., dynamic_space_member).

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as before.

  3. Document Level Security: Use the ${user.roles} substitution variable in a terms query: 

{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [ ${user.roles} ]
  }
}

Result: When a user logs in, if they are assigned to the IAS groups finance_space_staging and finance_space_dev, the DLS query automatically evaluated to "terms": { "space_name.keyword": ["finance_space_staging", "finance_space_dev"] }. The user is only shown logs where space_name exactly matches one of their assigned IAS groups.

Map this role to a general backend role pattern (e.g., finance_space*) to cover all relevant IAS groups.

 

High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch

Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)

1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :

Avoid using a plain wildcard (*) for index patterns in your DLS roles. This includes system indices (like .kibana), which can break Dashboards functionality when DLS is applied. Always use a targeted pattern like logs-*, otel-*

2. DLS and Write Permissions:

A user with a DLS-configured role must not be granted write permissions. If they index a document they cannot retrieve (due to DLS filtering), it creates invisible data they cannot manage. DLS is intended for read-only access control.

3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles

When a user with multiple roles (usually Admins) logs in, OpenSearch combines DLS rules from multiple roles using a logical OR. However if a restricted role with DLS is combined with a role with empty DLS, the unrestricted role will not override the DLS rule, and access remains restricted according to role with DLS.

This is the secure, expected behaviour:

  • Admin role: empty DLS

  • Restricted role: with a restricted DLS
  • Combined: restricted role takes precedence (since empty DLS does NOT override a restrictive one)

Background: The admin role has an "empty" DLS configuration which by default does not override a restrictive one. In Cloud Logging, plugins.security.dfm_empty_overrides_all is disabled, so empty DLS doesn‚Äôt override.

Workaround to Give Admins Full Access

  1. Duplicate the all_access role ‚Üí all_access_advanced

  2. Change index pattern: from * to a targeted pattern like logs-*
  3. Add a match-all DLS:  {"match_all":{}}
  4. Ensure admin backend role is mapped to this new role.

4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

For security and performance, use DLS filters with term query on a .keyword field.

# Option 1: works but has limitations

{ 
 "bool": { 
   "must": { 
     "match": { 
       "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
     } 
   } 
 } 
} 

vs. 

# Option 2: preferred
{ 
‚ÄØ "term": { 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
‚ÄØ } 
}
  • Although match  (combined with .keyword) works, it triggers analyzers and scoring logic.
  • Furthermore, it is not guaranteed to remain exact under future mapping or analyzer changes which are risky when used for authorization.
  • term is faster, safer, and the only deterministic option for Lucene-level DLS.
Term Look up: 

If you use term lookup queries (not the simple Term query) or other constructs, DLS falls back to Filter-level DLS instead of the most efficient Lucene-level DLS which might have to be considered when filtering on large data sets. (read more on DLS evaluation modes).

üîö

Official OpenSearch DLS documentation: https://docs.opensearch.org/2.19/security/access-control/document-level-security/

entry.title: Custom AI for the modern Administrator
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre an SAP BTP admin who feels like you‚Äôre always ‚Äúputting out fires,‚Äù this webinar is for you.

The thing is, custom AI isn‚Äôt just a buzzword anymore. With generative AI hub and Joule Studio, it can quietly become your co-pilot‚Äîspotting issues earlier, simplifying daily tasks, and freeing you up to focus on the work that feels strategic.

In ‚ÄúCustom AI for the modern Administrator,‚Äù we‚Äôll share real customer-inspired scenarios, walk through troubleshooting techniques, and show you how AI can reshape your day-to-day operations on SAP BTP. Think of it as a hands-on lab plus a candid conversation.

We‚Äôll do a live ‚Äúshow and tell‚Äù of configurations and tools, then open it up for Q&A so you can ask what‚Äôs really on your mind.  And if you‚Äôre eyeing the SAP Certified Associate ‚Äì SAP BTP Administrator path, this session will help you move in that direction.

Register now and let‚Äôs reimagine the admin role together.  https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/education/psd/2025/oct/e_oe_te_w_PSD_WEB_00011949.html

entry.title: Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂú® S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâà‰∏≠Êü•Êâæ CDS ËßÜÂõæ
entry.content:
Êú¨ÊñáÂÜÖÂÆπÁøªËØëHow to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edit... - SAP Community

 

Â¶ÇÊûúÊÇ®ÂØπBTPÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£ÔºåBTP‰∏™‰∫∫Á≤æÈÄâÂÜÖÂÆπÁõÆÂΩï | SAP Blogs ÂèØËÉΩÊúâÊõ¥Â§ö‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπ

 

ÁÆÄË¶ÅÊ¶ÇËø∞

ÈÄöËøá‰∏âÂ±ÇÊû∂ÊûÑÁöÑ S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºåÊÇ®Áé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞Ü ABAP ÂºÄÂèëÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºàADTÔºåÂú® Eclipse ‰∏≠ÔºâÁõ¥Êé•ËøûÊé•Âà∞Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÊµèËßàÂºÄÂèëÂØπË±°ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨ CDS ËßÜÂõæ„ÄÇÂàõÂª∫ ABAP Â≠òÂÇ®Â∫ìÊ†ëÂèØËÆ©ÊÇ®ÊåâÁªÑ‰ª∂ÂíåÂèëÂ∏ÉÁä∂ÊÄÅÊµèËßàÔºå‰ª•Êü•ÊâæÂ∑≤ÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑËßÜÂõæÁî®‰∫éÊÇ®ÁöÑÊâ©Â±ï„ÄÇ

 

ÊèêÈÜí‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºå‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØ S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºü

S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºàÊàñÂÖ¨Êúâ CEÔºâÊòØ SAP ÁöÑ SaaS ERP„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰πãÂâçË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ S/4HANA Cloud Âíå S/4HANA Public CloudÔºåËøôÁßç S/4 Âèò‰ΩìÂº∫Ë∞É‰∏éÊ†áÂáÜ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÁöÑÁ¥ßÂØÜÂ•ëÂêà„ÄÇËØ•Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÁî± SAP ÊâòÁÆ°ÂíåÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÇÂè™ËÉΩËøõË°åÊ∏ÖÊ¥ÅÊ†∏ÂøÉÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÂçáÁ∫ßÊåâÁÖßÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥Ë°®ËøõË°å„ÄÇ

 

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÂæàÈáçË¶ÅÔºü

Êç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåÊã•Êúâ 10,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏ÊØîÊã•Êúâ 100,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏Â§öÂæóÂ§ö„ÄÇÊã•Êúâ 1,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏ÊØîÊã•Êúâ 10,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏Â§öÂæóÂ§ö„ÄÇ

entry.title: Expose SAP CPI Integration Flows as APIs Using SAP API Management: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite empowers businesses to integrate applications and processes efficiently. One powerful capability is exposing CPI integration flows as APIs via API Management (APIM). This enables centralized governance, security, and monitoring of APIs. In this blog, we‚Äôll cover the step-by-step process to achieve this.

Step 1: Set Up SAP Process Integration Runtime

Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Instances & Subscriptions.

  • Create Service Instance
    • Service: SAP Process Integration Runtime
    • Plan: api
    • Instance Name: e.g. CPI_API_Instance
    • Assign all roles (except security roles)Create Service Key

      Click the ‚ãÆ (three-dot menu) ‚Üí Create Service Key ‚Üí Save credentials (Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL).

Step 2: Design & Deploy a Sample iFlow

In Integration Suite:

  • Create Package:
    Navigate to Design ‚Üí Integrations & APIs ‚Üí Create Package (e.g. Demo_API_Package).

  • Build iFlow:
    Add an HTTP Sender and a Content Modifier (set sample body content).
    Deploy the iFlow.

 

 

 

Step 3: Configure API Provider with OAuth2

In API Management:

  • Create API Provider:
    Navigate to Configure ‚Üí API Providers ‚Üí Create New.
    • Name: CPI_Provider
    • Connection Type: Cloud Integration
    • Host: Use host from Service Key
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials
      • Enter Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL

 

Step 4: Create & Deploy API Proxy

  • Create API Proxy:
    Select the API Provider ‚Üí Click Discover ‚Üí Choose deployed iFlow.
    Enable OAuth and provide credentials.
    • Proxy Name: flow-api-proxy
    • Save & Deploy.

 

Step 5: Test Your API

Use Postman:

  • Paste the Proxy URL
  • Send a request
  • Confirm the response from your iFlow.

 

Conclusion

By exposing SAP CPI integration flows as managed APIs through SAP API Management, you create a robust integration layer that blends flexibility with strong governance. This approach offers several key benefits:

  • Centralized Control: Manage all APIs from a single platform, making lifecycle management simple and efficient.
  • Enhanced Security: Protect your integrations with OAuth2 and other security policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Scalability & Reusability: Reuse APIs across multiple applications and business processes, cutting down development time and effort.
  • Comprehensive Monitoring: Gain full visibility into API performance and usage with built-in analytics and dashboards.

This setup not only streamlines integration but also supports modern API-driven architectures, enabling faster innovation and better interoperability across your enterprise. As a next step, consider adding features like rate limiting, caching, and custom policies in API Management to further boost performance and security.

entry.title: Introduction to SAP BTP commercial models, cost estimation, and cost management
entry.content:
Struggling to make SAP BTP pricing ‚Äújust click‚Äù for your customers?  You‚Äôre not alone‚Äîand that‚Äôs exactly why we created this session.

In ‚ÄúIntroduction to SAP BTP commercial models, cost estimation, and cost management‚Äù, we‚Äôll:

  • Break down SAP BTP commercial models in clear, simple terms
  • Compare consumption vs. subscription with real-world partner examples
  • Show how to estimate and manage costs so projects stay healthy and predictable

The thing is, when you‚Äôre confident on pricing and cost management, your SAP BTP conversations move faster‚Äîand deals close smoother.

If you‚Äôre an SAP partner in sales, pre-sales, architecture, or finance, this hour can seriously level up your next customer meeting.

Register now and bring pricing clarity to your SAP BTP strategy.  https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/education/psd/2025/oct/e_oe_te_w_PSD_WEB_00012034.html

entry.content:
